Package RautSoft.math.EQsolve

The package contains various classes to find zeros of a non-linear function of one variable or a system of non-linear equations of many variables.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
ZeroFinder The package contains various classes to find zeros of a non-linear function of one variable or a system of non-linear equations of many variables.
 

Package RautSoft.math.EQsolve Description

The package contains various classes to find zeros of a non-linear function of one variable or a system of non-linear equations of many variables. Currently it has the class ZeroFinderNR constructed from numerical methods.

Usage Examples

Example: Solving a equation of one unknown

 
  
          import static RautSoft.util.nrutil.*;
          import RautSoft.Interfaces.FunctionOfOneVariable;
          import RautSoft.math.fsolve.*;

          public class OneEquationEX {
    
          public static void main(String[] args) {
        
          FunctionOfOneVariable f = new FunctionOfOneVariable() {
          public double value(double x) {
          return (x-2)*(x-2);
          }
          };
        
          FunctionOfOneVariable df = new FunctionOfOneVariable() {
          public double value(double x) {
          return 2*x -4;
          }
          };
          ZeroFinder zf=new ZeroFinder();
          zf.MAXITS=10;
          double xopt = zf.rtnewt(f,df, -10,10,0.0001);
          System.out.println(zf.getLogs() );
          if (zf.getExitCode()==0){
          System.out.println("The optimal solution using rtnewt, xopt = " + xopt);
          }else {System.out.println("Optimal solution could not be obtained, see the errorLog");}
        
          zf.MAXITS=100;
          xopt = zf.rtnewt(f,df, -10,10,0.0001);
          System.out.println(zf.getLogs() );
          if (zf.getExitCode()==0){
          System.out.println("The optimal solution using rtnewt, xopt = " + xopt);
          }else {System.out.println("Optimal solution could not be obtained, see the errorLog");}
        
          ZeroFinder zf2=new ZeroFinder();//it has default MAXITS=200
          xopt = zf2.rtsafe(f,  df, -10,10,0.0000000000001);
          System.out.println(zf2.getLogs() );
          if (zf2.getExitCode()==0){
          System.out.println("The optimal solution using rtsafe, xopt = " + xopt);
          }else {System.out.println("Optimal solution could not be obtained, see the errorLog");}
        
          }
    
          }

Output:

          
          RautSoft Economics and Business Numerics:  Friday, April 22, 2005 11:18:42 PM PDT
          errors and logs from ZeroFinder
          Maximum number of iterations exceeded in rtnewt
          Optimal solution could not be obtained, see the errorLog

          RautSoft Economics and Business Numerics:  Friday, April 22, 2005 11:18:42 PM PDT
          errors and logs from ZeroFinder
          Maximum number of iterations exceeded in rtnewt
          The optimal solution using rtnewt, xopt = 1.99993896484375

          RautSoft Economics and Business Numerics:  Friday, April 22, 2005 11:18:42 PM PDT
          errors and logs from ZeroFinder
          Root must be bracketed in rtsafe
          The optimal solution using rtsafe, xopt = 1.9999999999999432

Example: Solving a system of equations of many unknowns(using mnewt)

The mnewt could be used to solve a system of equaitons of more than one unknown variables. Two public static methods avaialble, (1) mnewt() which requires for the user to provide the analytical Jacobian function as a MatrixFunctionOfManyVariables; (2) mnewtWithoutJackobian() does not require analysical Jackobian, it is calculated using finite difference method. 

 
  
          import static RautSoft.math.fsolve.ZeroFinderNR.*;
          import RautSoft.Interfaces.*;
          import RautSoft.math.fsolve.*;
          public class mnewtEX {
          public static void main(String[] args) {
          final int n=4;  // number of variables
        
          int N=4;
          int NTRIAL=5;
          double TOLX=1.0e-20,TOLF=1.0e-20;
        
        
          double xx;
          double []  x = new double [n];
          for (int i=0;i<x.length;i++)x[i]=1;
        
        
          VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables  fvec = new VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables(){
          public double [] value( double[] x){
          double [] fvec = new double [4];
          fvec[0] = -(x[0]*x[0])-(x[1]*x[1])-(x[2]*x[2])+x[3];
          fvec[1] = (x[0]*x[0])+(x[1]*x[1])+(x[2]*x[2])+(x[3]*x[3])-1.0;
          fvec[2] = x[0]-x[1];
          fvec[3] = x[1]-x[2];
          return fvec;
          }
          };
        
          MatrixOfFunctionsOfManyVariables  jack = new MatrixOfFunctionsOfManyVariables(){
          public double [][] value( double[] x){
          double [][] fjac = new double [n][n];
                
          fjac[0][0] = -2.0*x[0];
          fjac[0][1] = -2.0*x[1];
          fjac[0][2] = -2.0*x[2];
          fjac[0][3] = 1.0;
          for (int i=0;i<n;i++) fjac[1][i] = 2.0*x[i];
          fjac[2][0] = 1.0;
          fjac[2][1] = -1.0;
          fjac[2][2] = 0.0;
          fjac[2][3] = 0.0;
          fjac[3][0] = 0.0;
          fjac[3][1] = 1.0;
          fjac[3][2] = -1.0;
          fjac[3][3] = 0.0;
                
          return fjac;
          }
          };
          System.out.println("Carry out mnewt with numerical computaitons of Jackobian presenting each trial");
          for (int j=0;j<5;j++){
          System.out.println("Trial # " + (j+1) );
          mnewt(fvec,jack,x,TOLX,TOLF,j);
          for (int i=0;i< n;i++) System.out.printf("x[%d] = %10f and f[%d](x)= %10f\n", i, x[i], i, fvec.value(x)[i]);
          }
          for (int i=0;i<x.length;i++)x[i]=1;
          System.out.println("Carry out mnewt with numerical computaitons of Jackobian with default value of NTRIAL=10");
          mnewtWithoutJackbobian(fvec,x);
          for (int i=0;i< n;i++) System.out.printf("x[%d] = %10f and f[%d](x)= %10f\n", i, x[i], i, fvec.value(x)[i]);
    
          for (int i=0;i<x.length;i++)x[i]=1;
          ZeroFinderNR zr=new ZeroFinderNR();
          zr.NTRIALS=5;
          System.out.println("Carry out mnewt with numerical computaitons of Jackobian with NTRIALS reset to 5");
          mnewtWithoutJackbobian(fvec,x);
          for (int i=0;i< n;i++) System.out.printf("x[%d] = %10f and f[%d](x)= %10f\n", i, x[i], i, fvec.value(x)[i]);
          }
          }

Output:

          Carry out mnewt with numerical computaitons of Jackobian presenting each trial

          x[0] =   1.000000 and f[0](x)=  -2.000000
          x[1] =   1.000000 and f[1](x)=   3.000000

Example: Solving a system of equations of many unknowns(using newt)

The method newt does not require the user to provide analytical Jacobian. It is calucated numerically. 
          import static RautSoft.util.nrutil.*;
          import static RautSoft.math.fsolve.ZeroFinder.*;
          import RautSoft.Interfaces.*;

          /**
          *
          * @author  Lakshmi K. Raut
          */
          public class newtEX {
    
          public static void main(String[] args) {
        
          { //Ex1
          int n=2;
          pBoolean check = new pBoolean(false);
          double []  x = new double [n];
          x[0]=2.0;
          x[1]=0.5;
            
          VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables  func = new VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables(){
          public double [] value( double[] x){
          double [] f = new double [2];
          f[0]=(x[0]*x[0])+(x[1]*x[1])-2.0;
          f[1]=Math.exp(x[0]-1.0)+x[1]*(x[1]*x[1])-2.0;
          return f;
          }
                
          };
          newt(x,check,func);
          if (check.value) System.out.println("Convergence problems.");
          for (int i=0;i< n;i++) System.out.printf("x[%d] = %10f and f[%d](x)= %10f\n", i, x[i], i, func.value(x)[i]);
          }
          System.out.println("\nNow try another problem");
        
          {//Ex2:  Lets try the example from xmnewt
          int N=4;
          pBoolean check = new pBoolean(false);
          double []  x = new double [N];
          x[0]=2.0;
          x[1]=0.5;
          x[2] =1.0;
          x[3] =1.0;
          VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables  func = new VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables(){
          public double [] value( double[] x){
          double [] fvec = new double [4];
          fvec[0] = -(x[0]*x[0])-(x[1]*x[1])-(x[2]*x[2])+x[3];
          fvec[1] = (x[0]*x[0])+(x[1]*x[1])+(x[2]*x[2])+(x[3]*x[3])-1.0;
          fvec[2] = x[0]-x[1];
          fvec[3] = x[1]-x[2];
          return fvec;
          }
          };
          newt(x,check,func);
          if (check.value) System.out.println("Convergence problems.");
          for (int i=0;i< N;i++) System.out.printf("x[%d] = %10f and f[%d](x)= %10f\n", i, x[i], i, func.value(x)[i]);
          }
          }
          }

Output:

          x[0] =   1.000000 and f[0](x)=   0.000000
          x[1] =   1.000000 and f[1](x)=   0.000000

          Now try another problem
          x[0] =   0.453885 and f[0](x)=   0.000000
          x[1] =   0.453885 and f[1](x)=  -0.000000
          x[2] =   0.453885 and f[2](x)=   0.000000
          x[3] =   0.618034 and f[3](x)=   0.000000
